Comment: Some Corporations can't pass the costs on to the consumer because their consumers are not in Oregon.  Increasing their costs by 2.5% will make them unable to compete in the rest of the US or the world and they will either have to quit business or move.  Think RV manufacturing.  Most of it is now in the Midwest where it is central to raw materials and transportation.  If a Coburg or Harrisburg RV company has to charge 2.5% more than all those companies in Indiana, they lose.  Add in the transportation costs from Oregon to wherever and they really lose. If they are gone, local governments and school districts get no property tax money; and the State of Oregon gets no income tax money from their employees. It's not a matter of greed; it's a matter of economics.

Comment: The way seeds were modified before GMO is called mutagenesis. The breeder puts a bunch of seeds in a chemical bath or blasts them with radiation to force mutations. The mutant seeds are then grown and inspected for desirable traits. 100s of genes are modified in each trial. 

This is a completely unregulated practice that's been in use for about 100 years. Many organic crops were made this way. 

You already have lived long enough to see the manipulation of DNA; humans have been doing it in variety of ways for 10,000 years. We're just better at it now that we used to be.

Comment: |A brilliant move by Lamoriello.  This is a lot of annual money and the term is questionable but the competition for him likely demanded it. A third year  is likely a hoped for bonus whose cap cost they have thought hard about and decided to go with (maybe he'll  be on the coaching staff by then). Comment: Taxes for corporations have already dropped 50% in the last couple of decades - has that created more jobs and better paying jobs?

How is the government dealing with the reduced tax revenues? Cutting services to the employees! So we now have corps paying less and getting the same (and increasing their profits) while working Canadians pay the same tax as before but get fewer services.

Comment: Avoid creating subsidies for electric vehicles--as an immediate policy, even better idea!  Incentives, like any government grants/programming, are hard to kill once they have been implemented.

What are these enormous subsidies for gasoline fueled vehicles? Certainly not $8,000 (in Quebec) or $14,000 (in Ontario) per vehicle.  Near as I can tell, most of the so-called subsidies for gasoline-fueled vehicles is actually about costing environmental damage, health costs, etc. on the basis that the consumer purchase price doesn't factor in these post-purchase "costs".   Using the same logic, then cigarettes, fast food, booze, TV and internet....well, everything, for that matter, is being subsidized because the purchase price doesn't consider post-purchase "costs".  

Subsidies for EV's are an inefficient and expensive way to achieve carbon reduction, and the subsidies tend to end up in the pockets of the already-affluent.   It's bad policy.

Comment: One common misconception regarding college algebra is that you learn the basic arithmetic mentioned by the author in that class. As a college math professor for ten years, who has taught college algebra countless times, I am very familiar with the standard curriculum of a college algebra course. The course revolves around learning different families of functions, such as exponential, rational, logarithmic, etc. A quality course will spend a lot of time on modeling using each of these function families. For a more informed understanding of the current college algebra curriculum and the change in it's direction, read articles on "a modeling approach to college algebra". Regarding the alternative courses that are taught, these cover many applicable topics in math that very few people are exposed to, such as financial math, logic, and graph theory. My opinion is that these topics are just as important as those taught in college algebra and should be considered as a viable math alternative.

Comment: Mr. Roberts,
As do most words, the term "refugee" has a specific meaning.  Not everyone who immigrates to this country is a refugee.  It is not at all clear from this piece that either Mr. Gonzalez or Mr. Aguilar are refugees.  Even if they are refugees in the broad sense of the word -- that they are fleeing persecution in their home country, they are not refugees as the term is used in the current immigration conversation, as referring to a specific group of people who have been recognized as refugees by the UN and/or a particular government.  
It's good to use words correctly; otherwise one may cause confusion.

Comment: Dear Globe,
Please tell your readers what Mr. Leach is a professor of at the University of Alberta.

The idea that a major corporation falls victim to the sunk cost fallacy suggests that it is not finance. The grammar, in places, suggests that it is not english.

Perhaps flim-flammery?
read: " It was a decision that will likely allow them to save Keystone XL."

Now, even if Energy East was cancelled independently of Keystone, if Transcanada in reacting to the cancellation of Energy East dusts off Keystone, Mr. Leach will seem prescient. Post hoc ergo propter hoc errors will allow him to claim victory even with no causal link.

I would also like to point out that the word "likely" in the sentence above is the 10th use of this probabilistic phrasing. Allowing that by "likely" Mr. Leach intends that the probability of a statement being true is about 75%, the use of the word 10 times suggests the likelihood that this entire chain of events unfolded is around 6%. Not very likely at all.

Comment: I think its a mistake to characterize the "aging population" as a crisis. It is, in fact, the new normal. Only the smallest cohorts are now over sixty-five and the large bulge of the late boomers is still to hit. Then we will have reached what will be the norm for decades. The new ratio of working people to retired that rolls out between 2027 and 2032 is unlikely to change and our policies should assume that ratio. Programs like defined benefit private pension plans, good health insurance, the old age supplement, and well run nursing homes will help not hinder. Every support taken away from the elderly now will make it harder to adjust to a new reality that isn't going to go away. We need to understand, that the thirty-somethings, who face a difficult job market, are going to need those supports and need to start building them now. Every support taken away will have to be recreated in the future.

Comment: And most conservatives never bothered doing research on WHY things were written in Vatican II's  Constitutions, Documents and Decrees in the first place.   While changes did occur, Vatican II provided American Catholics with an officially sanctioned language for comprehending and discussing the sociocultural changes so many were already experiencing.  
Long before Vatican II, questions which had lain before the Church for many centuries---without open discussion were:
1) the role of bishops in their relationship to the bishop of Rome.
2) the place and role of lay people in the life and operations of the Church.
3) the understanding and place of religious liberty in the modern Church.
4) the Church's teaching on divine revelation and its source.
5) the Church's attitude toward and desire for relationship with the Jews.
6) the way Christian unity should be approached.
7) the reform and restoration of the Liturgy [in the vernacular], the catechumenate, and the diaconate.

Comment: Jeffrovich, EIF is a long term hold for me and I view it as a keeper.

Part of the current share price weakness is perhaps driven by Q1 results where FCF was lower than Q1 2016 and payout ratio based on FCF was very high.

However, the first quarter is always the toughest for EIF due to a variety of reasons. And additionally they did extra maintenance work in this quiet period for some of their businesses this year which largely caused the reduction in FCF (net of Capex).

On a rolling 12 month basis the payout ratio is fine. I see no concerns regarding the dividend and as I said it's a keeper in my books.

Comment: The standards against which potential drivers are judged are codified incompetence.  The testing against those standards is inadequate.  To expect drivers who lack the most rudimentary skills of observance, reaction, judgement and physical coordination to look out for the safety of other users of the road, no matter what motive method is employed, is foolish even suicidal.

The purpose of all transportation is efficiency, rapidly moving goods and people from Point A to Point B.  Demanding that competent drivers perform inefficiently in order to accommodate users of the roadways who are inefficient, no matter the motive method of the vehicle other than some commercial vehicles, is ridiculous.   Riding a bike at 5 mph in the traff lanes on Willamette during rush hour is stupid and invites bad reactions.

Safety and efficiency are products of competence.  Incompetence is the cause of accidents and traffic jams.  What changes do you think are more appropriate to address the real situation?

Comment: A more effective approach would be to follow BC's lead in enacting encouraging the other provinces to implement legislation similar to the Immediate Roadside Prohibition (IRP). The vast majority of impaired drivers are dealt with through an immediate administrative prohibition. BC's fatality rate from impaired driving has dropped drastically in real terms and when compared to other provinces. No criminal record as it is enacted through provincial legislation dealing with road safety. Why does it work? For a Criminal Code investigation, it will typically tie up two officers for four hours each (eight "man" hours.) An IRP can be administered in 15 minutes. In eight hours, an officer could conceivably intercept and deal with 4 x 8 = 32 impaired drivers. Higher probability of getting caught equals a change in behaviour.

Comment: I don't find this to be full of racist generalisations as someone else has commented . I find the point aptly made; that our abhorrence for individual rape incidents should not obscure the matrix from which these incidents spring; the "rape culture" as the writer puts it. 

When a woman is cat-called, when every passing man feels he has to make his presence known to you, when you are approached, touched, called out after and when comments of a sexual nature are muttered under the breath as you pass, we have a culture that makes rape possible. Mosiana is simply directing our attention to where the problem starts. Once we can agree on that, we can analyse how this situation came to be; but we need to see and agree that this is the reality, and that society's responses to it are racially biased. 

To say that it is racially biased is not to gloss over the rape of white women. All rape is horrendous; and for both black and white women it springs from the same patriarchal assumptions.

Comment: Hi, I'm a water/leakage management technology consultant from the UK. It is common all over the western world to reduce water network pressure and not to increase it. Higher network water pressure increases the flow rate of underground leaks; increases the water customers draw for their own needs (car washing/gardening); induce bursts which cause interruptions to customers' water supply and decrease pipe lifetime. The state of Washington may not have water scarcity issues but I don't see the sense in losing more water and damaging water infrastructure whilst poisoning nature with chlorinated water, all to give customers a luxuriously high water pressure. The more water that is lost from water networks, the more that needs to be drawn from nature. I don't see anything in this article that tells me why water pressures are being increased across the network to then only be decreased (at a massive cost) at the customer boundary.
I'd be really interested to know the backstory to this scheme

Comment: Hawaii could take advantage of its climate to revise the traditional school year. Teachers are always saying they have to reteach because kids forget over the summer. Why not have year-'round school with three-week breaks after each quarter, and take out most of August and September as a 6 week break. 
Or better yet, start running schools on trimesters. Mid-September, October, November, mid-December as trimester #1 (keeps Xmas and New Year holidays intact), January, February, March as #2 (keeps Spring Break intact), and April, May, June as #3. Only a few graduating Seniors might be impacted by the end of June timeline, but that shouldn't be too hard to fix.
That leaves school out all of July, August, and half of September--the hottest months in Hawaii.

Comment: Since I believe that human life begins at conception, how can I "concede"---what right do I have to "concede"---anything that would be a death warrant for certain human beings? 

What I CAN concede, and many times have, is that reasonable people of good faith can disagree about whether a person worthy of protection exists from conception onward.  This is where Roe v. Wade went off the tracks. I hate to concede it, but I must: New York, California, Ohio, whatever---all have the right to say that abortion is always just fine! As an American, I accept that that's the democratic process. By the same token, it can go the other way, too---and the Roe Court had to turn legal pretzels (and do lasting damage to constitutional law far beyond the scope of abortion) in order to reach the conclusion it did. On this point, read a classic, "The Wages of Crying Wolf," by Jon Hart Ely, who personally supported the right to abortion.  It's worthy of a Pulitzer. May God inspire your search for the truth.

Comment: I was an agnostic twice for about ten years each time.  The phenomenon of evil was not the reason either time.  

Of course the universe of billions of people can't be perfect in the eyes and mind of each single person.  Lions will kill and eat gazelles.  Storms will flood and destroy houses and kill people.  We have polluted the earth so that one river burned, another river no longer had fish, rain became acidic and killed forests.  We have built in flood zones and people died as a result.  Life can be tough and dangerous.  But it is life.  Truly amazing.  We can't understand it all.  We cannot control it.  But we can learn how to live realistically and humanely. And religion can help or hinder our doing so.  

I returned to the church, the far left liberal wing, a second time in May 2001.  Agnosticism fit well with my wishy-washy personality.  I could never quite do atheism; it seemed as dogmatic as religion and even more certain and less open than religion.

Comment: I agree that no one wants to pay, that is human nature. Rational tax structures, and government disclosures, would be set up in such a way so that what the public "gets" for each tax dollar is clearly visible, so the public feels more in control of what happens with their hard-earned money.

I'd prefer that we look at what our actual hard maintenance costs (materials and labor), including saving for replacement/upgrades and emergency funds, have been/should be, over past years, and a realistic inflation and interest calculation applied, to figure out just what our state-maintained roads actually cost. Apply to that pessimistic estimates of Federal spending and matching funds and then look at where we are really at.

With those hard(ish) numbers publicly known, we can then have an informed discussion over what level of services we can (and are willing) to pay for and figure out the best mix of taxes and user fees to do so, perhaps amending the state Con to allow dedicated funding.

Comment: AJ, this article makes claims about being able to run our country on renewables from 2020 onwards with existing technology. That's less than 3 years away. There is no projection that shows Lithium battery prices coming down by anything close to what is required to make these calculations work. 

Yes, we all hope for the breakthrough in battery technology that makes storage cost-effective. Then we are 100% in agreement: let's run the world on wind and solar. 

But if you are planning NOW for the next 20 years, you can't just do nothing and hope some new battery is invented. Similarly, if you're talking about 20GW of household solar, they need to install batteries now. And the batteries currently available (even the cheaper, less effective Lead batteries) are an order of magnitude too expensive. 

Besides, this study doesn't make a claim that it relies on yet-to-be-invented battery technology. It says with current technologies that 100% renewable is cost-effectively doable. It is not.

Comment: Canada doesn't have much of a horse in the combat aircraft race. Building our own would be a tremendous cost - well in excess of what even the F-35 is going to be. However, there are a lot of areas where Bombardier (and Viking) aircraft would be a good fit. The CP-140 fleet needs replaced, and the 737-based P-8 is the prime contender - a similarly sized and capable CS300-derived airframe would work well. The CS300 would also be an appropriate platform for an AEW&C aircraft a la the 737/Wedgetail Australia bought. The Global is an excellent SAR platform, as evidenced by the Raytheon Sentinel. New Guardian-400s from Viking would also be excellent replacements of the DHC-6s in the arctic. Support and transport missions are also possible - the C-130H tanker fleet needs a replacement, after all. A CSeries MRTT would be a very capable option. The list goes on.

- The elephant in the ointment in 'Renew My Church" is the existence of '‚ÄúThe Catholic Bishop OF Chicago,‚Äù A Corporation Sole" '. The parochial effect of this application of Illinois' constitutional law is that everything, real estate, and chattel, belongs to the Archbishop of Chicago. 
- Generally, there is an effort not to disregard canon law as it applies to parishes, in such dioceses the bishop or  staff will trump canon law with civil law in dealing with parish property, especially after a parish is dissolved.

Comment: I disagree on the value of post-secondary education. It used to be worth something, it really did. Now they're diploma-factories. If you can fog a mirror, and get a student loan, you can get admitted into some program.

And what for? Unless your chosen career requires a post-secondary piece of paper, why waste the time and money? First and foremost, they teach you how to get grades, not perform in a job. If someone really wants to study Shakespeare, anyone can read Shakespeare. Anyone. Anyone with an internet connection can find endless awesome papers written on his works. This information isn't hidden. It's all on-line, or in books.

I've met arts majors, psychologists, business majors, nurses, accountants, science majors. What they all had in common? They were all working in the trades.  They all said the same thing "I couldn't make enough money with my paper." 

You don't need a piece of paper. The institutions selling them need you to want one.

Comment: You don't have to be an attorney to read a Court decision.

This case covers Oregon public employee retirement law from 1940 through 1996 when the voters tried to get rid of the 6% pickup and most of the rest of PERS.

Retirement Cases decided in 1940, 1966, 1971, 1974, 1975, 1978, 1980 are cited and point to this result:

"The enactment of the PERS scheme in 1953 created constitutionally protected rights in PERS members.  PERS constitutes an offer by the state to its employees for a unilateral contract that may be accepted by the tender of part performance by those employees.   The PERS pension plan becomes vested in the state's employees on acceptance of employment.   The six percent pick-up, guaranteed rate of return, and sick leave credit are integral terms of plaintiffs' PERS pension contracts; they also are contractual obligations of the state under plaintiffs' PERS contracts."

State Police v. Oregon (1996)

http://law.justia.com/cases/oregon/supreme-court/1996/323-or-356.html

Comment: I agree a change is needed, but to what? 
A system where MPs are beholden to their parties (closed list proportional)? 
A system that creates permanent minorities (straight proportional with no cut-off points)? 
A system where someone can cast a "moral" vote that does not count (ranked ballots)? 
A system where some people have more representative voting than others (rural-urban votes)? 
A system deemed too complicated (single transferable ballot)? 
A system requiring multiple ballots (various regional mixed-member proportional representation systems)?

We need to work on the replacement system, not just make a random decision on what the replacement should be.

Comment: I agree that Property taxes are increasingly under the microscope for how to obtain more revenue (such as by increasing the proportion paid for lot/land size). (we renovated the kitchen and floors to keep up with the times).   The logic in taxing those who have been "lucky" in having equity in a house that has increased in value many times over is similar to taxing those who have won Lotto 649 because they're the ones who have the ability to pay.  Higher assessed value home owners already pay proportionately more when taxes go up on a percentage  basis, and those that rent don't pay education property taxes at all here in Alberta.  It's a complex issue.

Comment: Some talk here about our geography. There's nothing tiny about the population of Japan (127 million) especially given its land mass. How does it manage? Differently. No immigration. Therefore, Japan's society is racially/culturally homogeneous. Is that good? At the moment--it appears so. It's quick and easy to get consensus; get things done--and avoid social/dollar "diversity" costs.

Long term? No one knows. Success depends on more than immigration policy or population and its density. It depends on economic philosophy. Japan's government sells its debt--big debt!--to central Bank of Japan. Debt therefore is seen to "collapse." It's an experiment. Germany "experimented" by accepting a million migrants (of whom 75% face "long term unemployment..." Federal Labour Agency)

We know this about Japan: very little strife, confusion, anger or fear. Low unemployment; low suicide rate, .3 per 100,000 homicide rate (US: over 4%.), and, the most equal wealth distribution of any major economy.

Comment: I agree with what you say (that making laws is not the SOCs role and it might be dangerous for them to do so), however as I read the article it doesn't look like this is what he is saying but rather he is saying how he thinks it is.  If I'm right, he is wrong.

The SOC make laws.  They select what needs to be heard based on whether a hearing is necessary.  They do this by considering a number of factors (if a previous decision has already been made, if there is a compelling reason for the SOC to weigh in on a lower court decision, or if there is legal grid lock and the SOC needs to break the impasse on an important matter, if there is a societal need, etc).

The SOC just rules based on our laws.  New laws sometimes have to be made after a SOC ruling, but the SOC doesn't make the law.

Comment: LOL

There is no way I can forget...I'm from Saskatchewan, and my political awakening was the stunned experience of reading compilations of the reaction of the American printed media as Saskatchewan struggled with Tom Douglas' proposals, and our doctors rebellion. You know, "Red menace on our northern border," "Communism in North America," that sort of thing. I read voraciously, stunned by the utter lack of content or understanding of the issues as seen locally in favour of ranting slogans. 

The issues touched close to home because I had an uncle involved in the private health care insurance industry, and it was clear he would lose his livelihood--in fact, he ended up in Ontario, a senior bureaucrat in the health care system he feared. Irony of ironies.

Comment: Even in geographic isolation, any rich resources found on traditional FN lands were extracted by industry and the profits shipped south to major centres, which  did not benefit the  local FN communities. The Reserve system was created to contain and control, while allowing vast lands to become Crown lands, sold to non-native newcomers. Under the Indian Act today, status Indians continue to be wards of the government, with health care decisions and funding being federally controlled and managed from a downstream disease focus rather than upstream prevention and education.  My experience with Health Canada's FNIHB dental health coverage for First Nation families in B.C. was that it created worse outcomes and higher disease rates by not funding early prevention strategies and family education.

Comment: You need to read what is written more carefully. I didn't say I didn't believe there was a link.

My empirical evidence is personal observation and reporting.  The Oregon State Police Crime lab that I worked with back in the day always made sure the lab truck was gassed up and the batteries charged in the cameras just before a full moon based on the increased number of violent crimes that frequently occurred then.  

I had a friend who worked at the Oregon State Hospital in Salem who also related increased violent behavior at or near the full moon (hence 'lunatics' over the centuries).  I used to be on call in the DA's office and a full moon often coincided with domestic violence cases and violent crimes which I was personally called out on.  

'Empirical' is not the same as 'statistically significant' or 'immutable proof' or a lot of similar variations, as is shown in the examples in my citation.  

I am not ready to say there is no link; I am not prepared to say a link is proven.

Comment: It's not an understatement at all. It's an example of a journalist reporting the FACTS as known. Sergei Magnitsky was 37, but he was not in good health. He had gall bladder disease and pancreatis. His medical issues were duly diagnosed by a prison doctor, but the surgery she ordered was delayed by prison officials until Magnitsky was in very bad condition. On the day of his death, there is evidence that Magnitsky was having psychotic episodes, likely caused by his poor health. This may have lead to him fighting guards, as there were injuries on his body consistent with that scenario.

There's no question that Magnitsky received shoddy treatment in prison, and there's little doubt that an altercation took place on the day of his death. As to allegations that he was tortured in prison, that's not a belief based on evidence.

Philia -- œÜŒπŒªŒØŒ± -- is a dispassionate love. In Aristotle's Nicomachean Ethics, philia is used to mean loyalty to friends, family, and community, and would be the term used in a phrase such as "I love baseball".

Comment: Blake, I'm glad that you think Blue Planet's mission is valuable, and I'm not surprised that you think the rail is a boondoggle.  In general, most people in Hawaii intuitively understand what 100% clean electricity looks like. Everyone has seen wind mills and solar panels, and it is not a huge mental leap to imagine scaling wind and solar up - and adding a smarter grid and a decent amount of energy storage to achieve 100% clean electricity.
Unfortunately, transportation is more complex and there are many more misconceptions about the energy, land use and cost implications of different policies and infrastructure investments.  Here's a few questions I'd like you to contemplate: What % of Oahu residents have driver's licenses?  How much does it cost to own and operate a car annually?  How many parking stalls are needed for each car on the island and how much does it cost to build parking?  How much does it cost to operate TheBus?  What % of Oahu residents today (and in 2030) are over 65?

Comment: I still don't see where I mentioned anything about "how much profit there is", JSB. I said "25 to 30 percent in overhead." I never mentioned "profit" in my previous post. I did say "for-profit insurance companies", but if you hadn't noticed, "for-profit' is a different word than 'profit' and is an adjective, not a noun.
BTW: Overhead and profit are not the same. They are two different types of costs. Overhead costs are operating expenses, such as for necessary equipment, facilities, etc. Profit means revenue that remains after overhead expenses (AKA, net earnings).
Please cease distorting and lying about what I've said. I'll give you another chance, but one more time and I'll have to 'mute' you.

Comment: I think the methods used in the reality tv shows is what the main problem is -- to lose so much weight in a short amount of time is physically a shock to the human body. Now, your friend was smarter to shed the weight over time, not expecting to lose it all in 6 months. Slow, steady weight loss allows the body to adjust and respond to the weight changes and adapt. But to lose an average of 34 pounds a month (a little over 1 pound per day) is asking a lot of your body, it really is starvation. It's hard to count calories when you don't know what your body truly needs -- those FDA guidelines are based on a 2,000 calorie diet and unless you have the experts figure out what *your* body actually needs and will use and not turn to fat, it's a old calorie counting system that is not only misleading, it's flawed.

Comment: "Value investors believed that corporate profits and profit margins, which had benefited since 2008 because of declining commodity prices and a weak jobs market, were bound to revert to the mean."

Don't agree.  Yes, lower commodity prices have been a positive for "some" companies....but Apple, Google et al don't care where thermal coal or copper prices are.   The stock market of 2017 is not the stock market of 1952.   The largest companies in the market place are increasingly NOT capex intensive....and tend to generate a LOT of free cash flow, and have much higher EBIT margins than did the capex intensive companies that dominated the DOW etc. 60/65 years ago.


The weak job market has indeed been a factor ....  and the lack of real wage gains (until very recently) has helped profit margins....but it is NOT the driving force in corporate profits it was several generations ago.

And please do not lump all "value investors" into the same sub-set.

Comment: Mayor Wright Homes...that invokes some memories for me. I lived in the MWH housing shortly after it opened in the fifties. Yes, most of our neighbors were on welfare but I have some good memories of the place. I was a kid then. Remember the marble game, "In the puka?" The grassy areas of the housing were full of holes dug up by kids to play the game. We played touch football on the streets and hopscotch on the sidewalks, both boys and girls. 
We flew kites using nylon thread, believing it went a mile high. Would you believe some of my best memories were of Kaiulani School? Great principal, Mr. Ko and two memorable student teachers, Miss Seki and Miss Tottori, and wonderful fellow students. Granted the students were poor like me but well-behaved and top students (good readers were placed in separate classes, sort of like the English Standards Schools that came later).

Comment: All of the locations are immediately next to at least one of Toronto's liquid transmission lines. There are four companies involved, two of which own more than one line.

Three of the companies transport refined products. Normal operating pressure for these pipelines is in excess of 1,000 psi (usually either 1200 or 1440 psi). The fourth company operates a crude oil pipeline: it usually operates at over 600 psi.

These are certainly not low-pressure distribution lines. I will not list the locations here. All of them have been reported to the NEB: I took two NEB personnel on a tour of these sites in the summer of 2015. NEB sent an investigative Panel to examine the sites and gather additional information last Oct. 

The Panel was to submit a report to the Board in January but it remains internal. Consequently, I have no idea what, if anything, the NEB intends to do. 

Meanwhile, one senior planner with the City has assured me that such development "is good planning." 
That's a problem.

Comment: Do corporations get to say ‚Äúyes‚Äù and ‚Äúno‚Äù? 

I'm not sure why this question is paramount? To me, more important concern is whether elected governments, both federal and provincial, will retain the right to say "yes" and "no" where resource development is concerned or otherwise be subordinated to a broad aboriginal veto. I'm not overly concerned about the UNDRIP due to the fact that such declarations generally have greater moral than legal impact and by-and-large aren't enforceable. Comment: Thank you for writing this and for speaking up. It's nice to know there are educators who truly care about kids that have special education needs and who are willing to speak up. 
I adopted 2 kids that I was told would have a lot of special needs. I never thought that the biggest barrier to getting them help would be our local school district. I fought the fight until I realized that while I might win a few battles, that the war over getting my children the help that they needed would go on for as long as I could last. The district was sanctioned for 5 years for repeated violations of Sped laws, but they continued to violate. It was not just my kids but many kids who needed special services. 
I pulled all 3 of my kids out of school and attempted to home school them while working 40 plus hours a week.  1 of the 2 graduated from high school, the other 1, at age 28, is still trying to earn a diploma. The third one, (she was gifted) got a GED. All 3 hold down jobs, 2 live independently.

So, consider the safety of the BC citizens and environment and move the oil by pipeline, not rail car. Oil will move.

Comment: Many Canadians are unaware that in the immediate postwar decades, federal and provincial governments funded "Homes for Unwed Mothers" in every Canadian province. Over 300,000 unmarried mothers were systematically separated from their babies during this period. Mothers report verbal, physical, psychological, and sexual abuse in these homes, and the Canadian government has so far done nothing to acknowledge these wrongs.  Origins Canada advocates for a Committee to Investigate such as the one held in Australia to uncover the  illegal, unethical and human rights abuses in adoption policies and practices in both Indigenous and Non-Indigenous contexts. This type of inquiry may serve to validate the lifelong psychological and intergenerational damage to families by draconian adoption policies and practices, and to provide mental health and healing services to those denied them so many years ago. 
Valerie Andrews, Executive Director 
Origins Canada: Supporting Those Separated by Adoption

Comment: The fundamental problem is that the combination of unforseen circumstances and poor decisions undermines a lot of life's plans. When Social Security was set up, nobody expected beneficiaries to live for as long as they do now, or for economic growth rates to slow. Private sector defined benefit plans never foresaw the massive intensification of competition that forced many sponsors out of business. When circumstances change, so too must our plans, and many long cherished assumptions. For example, Federal employees have the Thrift Savings Plan -- a defined contribution plan that invests in index funds. Australia has mandatory savings in Superannuation funds, which are defined contribution plans. To say we have no choice but to raise taxes even higher to bailout PERA yet again (with no promise of improved government performance) is pure falsehood.

Comment: Your "facts" are wrong. Under the legislation DOC had to work with at the time-under two different Administrations, made it a law that any new construction or expansion  had to be financed by local communities. The decision to build the large prison was made by the previous administration based on the fact that the Mat-Su Borough was the only one that stepped up- unfortunately none of the rural communities did. There were never funds available for needed expansion in Bethel or Nome. The desire was to get prisoners out of the Private prisons in AZ and Colorado. That was accomplished. One might argue that we should have left them there- or refused to build the prison unless it was located in South Palmer- but not that there was a pot of money for rural expansion that had been redirected somehow to Goose Creek. I find it ironic now that folks who wanted to bring the AK prisoners home and get them out of dysfunctional private prisons now attack the folks that accomplished that.

Comment: Nick, good article.  The Brady Rule or exculpatory evidence (evidence favorable to the defendant) cannot be with held by the prosecution.  This principle is essential to a fair and honest trial. A prosecutor would not last long in the business by routinely withhold evidence.  Although, attorney's are not highly regarded... they have rules that must be followed.  Each prosecutor has a different way of presenting his case.  Outcomes at a trial can be very different depending on the quality of the prosecution. Justice is very illusive.  A trial does not guarantee justice or fairness.  Just a simple trial of before peers (or by a judge). Please remember what anything that you say can and will be used against you.  There is nothing that says anything can and will be used in your favor.  Police are not required to speak in your defense unless you call them as your witness. You tell a detective that you loved your wife but you killed her. All he is going to say is that you killed her.

Comment: (Sigh) No, this does not serve to make the street safer. If the problem was a vehicle stopping for a pedestrian in one lane but not the other, then the obvious solution is to remove a travel lane, not to make a one-way street two ways, which is known to INCREASE pedestrian deaths and injuries. 

This functionally adds car capacity (since Lawrence as a two-lane one-way road never had enough traffic to utilize the redundant lane). Adding lane capacity for cars has one very well-known effect: it causes more trips to be made by car. This well-proven concept is called induced demand and even car-crazy CalTrans has acknowledged that they must alter their policies because of what this means.

Since 2008, Eugene has lost 9100 cyclists, pedestrians and bus riders from the commuting population. Coincidentally, it has added 8900 cars to that pool. This is the sort of project that makes that happen. Bad as it is, the white-washing of calling it a Vision Zero project is truly galling.

Comment: Perhaps the author would have preferred if the Spanish or Portuguese had settled North America... 
The suggestion that pre-settlement North America was some harmonious society is rooted in unapologetic contempt for reality. North America is never going to go backwards - Canada didn't become one of the most advanced and richest societies in the world by accident. Our infrastructure: schools, hospitals, roads, environmental stewardship - are all a function of progress and value creation stemming from European settlement.  The idea of pre-settlement utopias have no basis in historical fact: life was hard, violent, and short prior to Europeans arriving in North America.

Comment: Great story about John Wesley that may be apropos:

Wesley was an ardent preacher and scholar, but secretly felt he was a fake.   He had lots of knowledge and was doing all kinds of works, but didn't really feel like an authentic Christian.

Later, he went on a voyage and there was a storm at sea.   Very frightening in those days, and Wesley was near scared to death of dying and ashamed of it to boot.   Where was his faith, he wondered?   

He noticed that some German Christians of another sect were together singing hymns while the storm raged.   They seemed at peace.   How could this be?   What did they know that he didn't?

The storm passed, and the next day, Wesley swallowed his pride and approached the German pastor, inquiring of him why he and his people were not afraid.

The pastor said, "you either believe that Jesus died on the cross for your sins and gave you salvation, or you don't."

Comment: So you think there wasn't a single rational justification for the age-old, virtually UNIVERSAL definition of marriage as one man, one woman?  What hubris.

Your citation of Article 10 of the Declaration of Human Rights does nothing to support you cause.  The right to marry is FUNDAMENTAL in the United States as well, and yet it woud have been though laughable, until recently, to say that this fundamental right to marry included the right to marry someone of the same sex.  Why?  Because "marriage," by definition, meant one man, one woman (although in some instances, polygamy), but never man-man or woman-woman.    Note, by the way, that the Declaration, Article 10, says "without any limitation due to race, nationality or religion."  It does not forbid a prohibition on grounds of sex, meaning man marrying man or woman marrying woman.  Indeed, such a prohibition would have been though absurd when the Declaration was passed in 1948, because the very idea of such "marriage" was absurd.

Comment: The outside of the heated column cools, so water vapour condenses, forming a slightly conical cloud.  Inside that cloud wall, the rest of the heated column is still rising.  It is basically a pump lifting water from sea level to the top of the troposphere.
.
As with any vapour cycle engine, evaporation is fastest at the highest temp., and condensation is fastest at the coldest temp.  The bigger the temperature difference, the faster the pump works.
.
Air at 40C can hold more than twice as much water as air at 25C.  Water at 40C is more than twice as ready to evaporate as at 25C.
At the top, the condensed water is thrown out radially.
.
If the input water temperature and sea-level air temperature are high, and the bottom-to-top temp. difference is big, the pump works really hard.  The harder it pumps, the lower the pressure at the bottom, which sucks in more moister air, faster.
.
Irma was a big pump:
near record low pressure at sea level,
near record low temperature at high altitude.

Comment: The pundits have been out in force on this issue but I do not see any competent comments.

When the US opts out of NAFTA it must give its partners six months notice. The US government must then change some trade laws to support its actions. This process may take longer than six months if recent Congressional gridlock is anything to go by. Legislative changes may extend the transition period in order to mitigate the disruption to some states.

Furthermore, if the US opts out of NAFTA we in theory fall  back onto the FTA which the US may not want to change. If they do there will likely be another negotiating process that is unlikely to begin until NAFTA is officially dead.

Overall, the affects of the demise of NAFTA could play out over several years, giving companies lots of time to adjust.

The stuffed shirts giving opinions on this issue seem ignorant of all this or are ignoring it in order to make broad brush statements that the sky is falling.

Comment: In the public sector salaries at the top-end are low while salaries in the mid and low-end are high.

If you were to look at something like a lawyer or especially an executive for a crown corporation (or similar level of management responsibility within the government-proper) salaries are low as compared to what is offered in the private sector.  However if you look at more mid-range employees, your typical "office worker" kind of jobs in administration, communications, etc. salaries are pretty generous if not a bit on the high side.  At the low-end of job compensation, for entry level workers, clerks and such, salaries in the public sector tend to be quite generous.

Comment: Check out Dr. Robert Epstein's work. In exploring sexual orientation, he surveyed a large sample of men & women & found that sexual orientation was on the same sort of continuum we see for many measures. He found that very few people were strictly hetrosexual or strictly homosexual, but fell somewhere 0% to 100% either or. Where people fell on that spectrum impacted what types of relationships they were comfortable with. Someone 80% heterosexual could be happy going their entire life in only straight relationships, while someone 30% heterosexual - i.e. 70% homosexual, might have sex with the opposite sex but would probably be more comfortable in a homosexual relationship. It depends on degree & other factors, including one's family & society's attitudes. 

On the other hand, when he measured gender characteristics he found that most adults are right in the middle with a mix of both feminine & masculine traits. Hyper-either gender was rare - but those outliers might explain dysphoria.

Comment: My first impression of Fairbanks in May of 1990 was "What a dump. I bet I end up living here." I ended up living here. It is decidedly not a dump.

After several years in Denali (where I met my now wife) we settled in Fairbanks for better job prospects. Initially I wasn't sure about the place but as I came to learn the extensive trail system the mountain biker in me went nuts. I also found plenty of things to get involved in because Fairbanks residents have to create their own good times. People here are doers. When you meet someone questions don't revolve around jobs, we ask where have you hiked/biked/hunted/fished/climbed/etc. In other words, how have you taken advantage of this place and what it offers? You can go to a party and find a millionaire swapping trail tales with a plumber and they've known each other for years and you can't tell which is which from the looks of them.

As for suggestions, visit in March. There is no finer place on Earth than Fairbanks, Alaska, in March.

Comment: No they would not be upholding the law.  

The Supreme Court of Canada dealt with that issue in 1985 when it determined that the lack of an oral hearing for a refugee claimant before an independent tribunal was unconstitutional. See Singh v Canada (Minister of Employment and Immigration), [1985] 1 S.C.R. 177. Singh also determined that any person in Canada even without legal status was protected by the Charter.

As a result any person in Canada even without immigration status has a right to have their claim to refugee status determined in accordance with the procedures that were passed into law post Singh and now are part of the IRPA.

Comment: We are not going to "eliminate" fossil fuels.  It is depletion that will cause their decline.  The easy to extract, cheap, concentrated fossil fuels are mostly a memory at this point, now we are going after the difficult to extract, more expensive, lower quality fossils.  It is similar to how the logging industry used to cut down very old trees and now is mostly focused on small trees with much less value, except trees only take a few centuries to grow back to old growth and petroleum deposits take eons.

Malthus did not anticipate fossil fuels.

We've also strip mined fisheries around the world, are destroying top soils, fresh water supplies, deforestation, desertification.  There are ways to reverse these problems but we are not doing much beyond platitudes, political blame and other distractions.  Sanger's politics had problems but the fact of overpopulation is very real.  So is the problem of overconsumption.

Toxic sprays in farming damage soil, organic regenerative ag is needed.

Comment: "Fluctuations in economic time series are caused by seasonal, cyclical and irregular movements. A seasonally adjusted series is one from which seasonal movements have been eliminated. Seasonal movements are defined as those which are caused by regular annual events such as climate, holidays, vacation periods and cycles related to crops, production and retail sales associated with Christmas and Easter. It should be noted that the seasonally adjusted series contain irregular as well as longer-term cyclical fluctuations. The seasonal adjustment program is a complicated computer program which differentiates between these seasonal, cyclical and irregular movements in a series over a number of years and, on the basis of past movements, estimates appropriate seasonal factors for current data." Statistics Canada

Comment: The need for sisters has declined for a couple of reasons.

The massive overlapping patchwork of government social programs, with NGOs, and other programs - some funded by other churches, nongov's etc....has swooped in and done what the sisters used to do....teaching, rehabilitation programs, other forms of training, food banks, nursing, you name it.

No longer a need.

They also "disappeared" to the parishes...no one knows that there are sisters doing good nearby....because they live in apartments and don't wear habits.

So they have 'gravitated" to "causes"..Gramlich etc. etc..essentially becoming thorns in their bishop's side (and their own superiors). 

Given their invisibility..it's hard to raise funds to take care of them.

They are now consolidating with other orders to economize their own care.  10-15 years from now....they'll be no more. Maybe a few orders, contemplative, or the orthodox ones. 

Sad as it is, these are the facts. 

Net: the government has done away with them.

Comment: Taking off at a high rate of speed does not indicate the rider was speeding. My motorcycle goes from 0-60 in 3 seconds, obviously I can reach 45-50mph sooner than that. Comment: "Modifying the fuel delivery, intake and exhaust from the original certified configuration is against federal law"

Defeating or tampering with emissions control devices is against the law. However, not all intake and exhaust system modifications or replacements count as "defeating or tampering with emissions control devices".

It is perfectly legal under federal (and CA and CO) law to replace an intake or exhaust system as long as any associated emissions control devices (e.g. EGR system, O2 sensors, catalytic converter, etc.) are still connected and operational. Since my exhaust and intake systems involved no such emissions control devices, their replacement was perfectly legal.

My injectors *might* be something else...

It was World War II that impacted Europe and Middle Europeans. 
It makes a difference... where someone came from and when....

Comment: The opponents' opinions are not based on valid facts, but stem from emotion - emotion stoked by the Tides Foundation funded shills.  

A seven-fold increase in tanker traffic that will cause congestion so great that spills are inevitable?  Tanker traffic so dense the Orca whales will surely perish?  Not so.  Only 25.5 km of Burrard Inlet will see a seven-fold increase.  Once in the Georgia Strait and the Strait of Juan de Fuca, the one additional tanker per day from Kinder Morgan will be joining the 1,100 tankers and the 13,000 ocean going vessels already transiting the area annually.
